Title:
Ectomycorrhizal morphology and pure culture establishment of
Lactarius section Deliciosi and its relative taxa from mycorrhizal root
tips
Keywords:
Colony morphology, Hatsutake, Laticifer, Molecular
identification, Mycorrhizal isolation, Saffron milk cap
Abstract:
Lactarius section Deliciosi includes various economically
important edible ectomycorrhizal (ECM) species represented by L.
deliciosus known as saffron milk cap. However, most species of this
section are known to perform slow growth on artificial agar media, and
report of fungal isolation from ECM root tips is limited. Present study
aimed to develop efficient method for obtaining pure cultures of
Lactarius section Deliciosi and its allied taxa from their ECM root
tips. Root systems connected to the basidiomata of L. akahatsu, L.
tottoriensis, L. hatsudake, L. subindigo and L. laeticolor via
rhizomorphs were sampled and tested. ECM root tips having yellowish or
orangish laticifers, which were confirmed by the differential
interference contrast microscopy were surface-sterilized with 0.1%
aqueous calcium hypochlorite solution and inoculated onto MNC agar
medium containing antibiotics. Mycelia that emerged from inoculated ECM
fragment were transferred to another fresh MNC medium to establish a
pure culture. Species identification of the cultures was performed by
PCR-RFLP and molecular phylogenetic analyses targeting the nrDNA ITS
region. As a result of this process, we established pure cultures of
five Lactarius spp. and more than 50% isolation rates were achieved in
all species. Mycelial colonies of L. akahatsu, L. hatsudake and L.
subindigo were light-yellow with greenish-blue patches on MNC, but those
of L. laeticolor and L. tottoriensis were deep orangish and grew slowly.
Our procedure proved to be an effective method for obtaining pure
cultures of some species of Lactarius.
